Award.AwardTitle: Carbon in karst: Investigating sources, transport mechanisms and isotopic fractionation to advance the interpretation of speleothem climate records
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will investigate the environmental controls on carbon isotopic composition of speleothem in order to refine this tool for paleo-environmental analysis. The transfer of carbon from vegetation to speleothem calcite is mediated by multiple processes, many of which are poorly understood and some heretofore unrecognized. Understanding of these processes can be significantly improved though careful empirical examination of a well-characterized karst setting. Project will study the sources, transport mechanisms and isotopic fractionation of carbon in multiple caves of the karst system in central Texas. Specific hypotheses to be tested are: 1) the carbon isotope composition of dissolved inorganic carbon in cave drip water is strongly influenced by deeply rooted plants (C3 trees) and only minimally by shallowly rooted plants (grasses and herbs;, 2) CO2 is transported into these caves in both the gas and liquid phases; 3) calcite precipitated in the caves is not in C isotope equilibrium with water entering the caves and the kinetic isotope effects responsible for this disequilibrium occurs primarily by degassing of CO2 from drip water rather than by calcite precipitation; and 4) the magnitude of kinetic isotope effects varies seasonally, can be quantified, and may thus provide new applications to paleoclimatology.
The most important impact of the proposed research will be to provide a more useful tool for the speleothem and paleoclimate research community. In addition, the research will support and train students and results will be communicated to high school students and teachers through a well-established educational program at the University of Texas Austin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chemical composition of stalagmites and other calcium carbonate formations inside caves provide some of the best records that we have of environmental conditions over the past several hundred thousand years. In particular, oxygen isotope ratios (18O/16O) in speleothems are commonly measured to reconstruct past changes in rainfall, an approach which has been instrumental in the modern understanding of glacial-interglacial cycles, the variability of monsoons and in general the ways in which climate perturbations propagate around our planet. When the oxygen isotope ratios of calcium carbonate minerals are measured, the carbon isotope ratios (13C/12C) are almost always measured too (i.e. they come for free with the oxygen measurements), but the factors controlling carbon isotope ratios are less well understood and perhaps for this reason they are less commonly interpreted and/or reported. Carbon isotope ratios in speleothems might record vegetation changes and other environmental signals complimentary to oxygen isotope records and could thus provide valuable additional information at no extra cost. Therefore, the objective of this project was to better understand the carbon isotope ratios in speleothems.

The research was designed to address two primary questions: 1) what is the source of carbon in cave air CO2, cave drip waters and speleothems and 2) how do in-cave processes influence the carbon isotope composition of speleothems? The approach involved the collection and analysis of gases, waters and carbonate minerals from soils and caves in central Texas. The conclusions of the study are as follows: 1) the primary source of carbon is not soil as previously thought, 2) decomposing tree roots and/or other organic matter from trees in fractures in the bedrock (i.e. below the soil) above caves is the primary source of carbon, and 3) drip rate, degree of ventilation and the chemical composition (degree of supersaturation) of water dripping from cave ceilings are the processes within caves that affect carbon isotope compositions.
